commit_message:
Add microsecond support to timeutils.utcnow_ts()

Now we have the ability to generate a timestamp with microseconds.

Change-Id: I34d51b71c01df02bef46639149fde08f89f0e110
Signed-off-by: Paul Belanger <paul.belanger@polybeacon.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.utils refs/changes/36/147736/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_utcnow_ts_microsecond(self): skynet_self_aware_ts = 872835240.000123 skynet_dt = datetime.datetime.utcfromtimestamp(skynet_self_aware_ts) self.assertEqual(self.skynet_self_aware_ms_time, skynet_dt) # NOTE(kgriffs): timeutils.utcnow_ts() uses time.time() # IFF time override is not set. with mock.patch('time.time') as time_mock: time_mock.return_value = skynet_self_aware_ts ts = timeutils.utcnow_ts(microsecond=True) self.assertEqual(ts, skynet_self_aware_ts) timeutils.set_time_override(skynet_dt) ts = timeutils.utcnow_ts(microsecond=True) self.assertEqual(ts, skynet_self_aware_ts)

subject: Force glance recheck for kernel/ramdisk on rebuild
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-12-18 13:37:47.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/af226d76a02083d83b8e4c1871f9ca8bb2ec13ad', 'message': "Check glance for new kernel and ramdisk on rebuild

We can't rely on the presence of a kernel and ramdisk on the
node to mean that we don't need to fetch new ones. It's possible
that the rootfs disk has changed, and uses new kernel and ramdisk.
It's also possible that someone has updated the kernel for the
image that we were already using, so we need to hit glance every
time.

commit_message:
Force glance recheck for kernel/ramdisk on rebuild

When doing a rebuild, clear the instance_info's kernel
and ramdisk values, to force the deploy driver to check
glance. This is necessary as those values may have changed
without us knowing.

closes-bug: #1401501

Change-Id: I8d7831789d21d3a2dcafd614989cf1e53dbedd70

commit_message:
Add explicit cleanup to test_ports

Currently, resources are cleaned up as part of test class teardown.
The number of subnets this class creates has increased to the quota
maximum and no longer runs when tenant isolation is disabled unless
things get cleaned up per-test.

Also, this removes a duplicate test case.

Change-Id: Ica58eb8da471282f35ff7c05cafcb64d4fd73ba6
Closes-bug: #1411794

commit_message:
bump lockfile to >=0.10

lockfile 0.8 appears to be incompatible with most of the packages that
actually use lockfile. The 0.10 release stream is pbr based and on
stackforge. We should bump this to reflect reality, and let the
"install all global-requirements" test pass.

Change-Id: If04e2f1e926e98be32a0e852fc4d0f27ea92b04f

commit_message:
Made run_tests.sh use tox to run checks

Now run_tests.sh script will use tox to run PEP8 checks.
This will allow to use run_tests.sh in Jenkins build scripts and
that step is required to further improvements of OSTF tests.

This is a step required to unify our CI jobs configuration.

Change-Id: I51012b2d633557141baebd5669db256dd5e99efd
Partial-Bug: #1404892
(cherry picked from commit c0e9862e6ab8d846b0db4d3e3ded6142ee3a5f3e)

added_lines: # Copyright 2015 Mirantis, Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. echo " -p, --pep8 Just run pep8" echo " -P, --no-pep8 Do not run pep8" echo " -h, --help Print this usage message" -P|--no-pep8) no_just_pep8=1;;no_just_pep8=0 function run_tests { # This variable collects all failed tests. It'll be printed in # the end of this function as a small statistic for user. local errors="" # Enable all tests if none was specified skipping all explicitly disabled tests. if [[ $just_pep8 -eq 0 ]]; then if [ $no_just_pep8 -ne 1 ]; then just_pep8=1; fi fi # Run all enabled tests if [ $just_pep8 -eq 1 ]; then run_pep8 || errors+=" pep8_checks" fi # print failed tests if [ -n "$errors" ]; then echo Failed tests: $errors exit 1 fi exit } function run_pep8 { echo "Running pep8 ..." tox -epep8 -v } run_tests

commit_message:
Made run_tests.sh use tox to run checks

Now run_tests.sh script will use tox to run PEP8 checks.
This will allow to use run_tests.sh in Jenkins build scripts and
that step is required to further improvements of OSTF tests.

This is a step required to unify our CI jobs configuration.

subject: More verbose help messages
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-01-16 21:16:53.000000000', 'files': ['solumclient/commands/languagepack.py', 'README-CLI.rst', 'solumclient/commands/assembly.py', 'solumclient/commands/base.py', 'solumclient/commands/component.py', 'solumclient/solum.py', 'solumclient/commands/__init__.py', 'solumclient/common/cli_utils.py', 'solumclient/tests/common/test_cliutils.py', 'solumclient/commands/pipeline.py', 'solumclient/tests/test_solum.py', 'solumclient/commands/plan.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-solumclient/commit/55874a239b50a9ad704b44d2c025ff3151c54708', 'message': 'More verbose help messages

Help messages are now hand-crafted instead of
being generated by the CommandBase class. On
error, the client should return a relevant help
message about the subcommand tree, and also any
applicable error messages raised.

ArgumentParser has been subclassed to control both
the help messages and also more completely rein in
the sys.exit() behavior it is prone to.

To cut down on the size of solum.py, the command
classes have been moved to their own subdirectory.

commit_message:
More verbose help messages

Help messages are now hand-crafted instead of
being generated by the CommandBase class. On
error, the client should return a relevant help
message about the subcommand tree, and also any
applicable error messages raised.

ArgumentParser has been subclassed to control both
the help messages and also more completely rein in
the sys.exit() behavior it is prone to.

To cut down on the size of solum.py, the command
classes have been moved to their own subdirectory.

Change-Id: I0b4d94b3e841c6cddac1033a0fcd7d1df6e1dfc9

s trying to break the commands into their own dir

Change-Id: I43113870f2d1828b8dd84b4ed8c968fbc74500b1

added_lines: from solumclient.commands.base import CommandsBase from solumclient.common import yamlutils from solumclient.openstack.common import cliutils from solumclient.v1 import plan as cli_plan class PlanCommands(CommandsBase): """Commands for working with plans. Available commands: solum plan list Print an index of all available plans. solum plan show <PLAN> Print details about a plan. solum plan create <PLANFILE> [--param-file <PARAMFILE>] Register a plan with Solum. solum plan delete <PLAN> Destroy a plan. Plans with dependent assemblies cannot be deleted. """ def create(self): """Create a plan.""" self.parser.add_argument('plan_file', help="A yaml file that defines a plan," " check out solum repo for examples") self.parser.add_argument('--param-file', dest='param_file', help="A yaml file containing custom" " parameters to be used in the" " application. Check out solum repo for" " examples") self.parser._names['plan_file'] = 'plan file' parsed, _ = self.parser.parse_known_args() with open(parsed.plan_file) as definition_file: plan_definition = definition_file.read() definition = yamlutils.load(plan_definition) if parsed.param_file: with open(parsed.param_file) as param_f: param_definition = param_f.read() definition['parameters'] = yamlutils.load(param_definition) plan = self.client.plans.create(yamlutils.dump(definition)) fields = ['uuid', 'name', 'description', 'uri', 'artifacts'] data = dict([(f, getattr(plan, f, '')) for f in fields]) artifacts = copy.deepcopy(data['artifacts']) del data['artifacts'] cliutils.print_dict(data, wrap=72) self._show_public_keys(artifacts) def delete(self): """Delete a plan.""" self.parser.add_argument('plan_uuid', help="Tenant/project-wide unique " "plan uuid or name") self.parser._names['plan_uuid'] = 'plan' parsed, _ = self.parser.parse_known_args() plan = self.client.plans.find(name_or_id=parsed.plan_uuid) cli_plan.PlanManager(self.client).delete(plan_id=str(plan.uuid)) def show(self): """Show a plan's resource.""" self.parser.add_argument('plan_uuid', help="Plan uuid or name") self.parser._names['plan_uuid'] = 'plan' parsed, _ = self.parser.parse_known_args() response = self.client.plans.find(name_or_id=parsed.plan_uuid) fields = ['uuid', 'name', 'description', 'uri', 'artifacts'] data = dict([(f, getattr(response, f, '')) for f in fields]) artifacts = copy.deepcopy(data['artifacts']) del data['artifacts'] cliutils.print_dict(data, wrap=72) self._show_public_keys(artifacts) def list(self): """List all plans.""" fields = ['uuid', 'name', 'description'] response = self.client.plans.list() cliutils.print_list(response, fields) def _show_public_keys(self, artifacts): public_keys = {} if artifacts: for arti in artifacts: if arti.content and ('public_key' in arti.content): public_keys.update( {arti.content['href']: arti.content['public_key']}) if public_keys: print('Important:') print(' Solum has generated SSH keypair for your ' + 'private github repository/ies.') print(' Please add these public SSH keys as github deploy keys.') print(' This enables solum assembly create to securely ' + 'clone/pull your private repository/ies.') print(' More details on github deploy keys: ' + 'https://developer.github.com/guides/' + 'managing-deploy-keys/#deploy-keys\n') for href, pub_key in public_keys.items(): print('%s :\n %s' % (href, pub_key))

commit_message:
Add the ability to skip requirement commits

If a bunch of commits were around requirement updates
by the requirement update bot it's pretty safe to just
skip these noisy commits and not show them (we show the
requirement changes later in the notes anyway).

Change-Id: I79296b96021a992cbe5d043191a1976c8b5f19f2

commit_message:
Add helpful messages when authN'ing with password

Setting up auth options can be complicated, and we currently don't
do any checking before we build all our auth parameters to send off
to keystoneclient. We should do some basic checking to guide new
users.

Change-Id: I9c88f1c9637b3870c151952ecc797aaf65be271a
Closes-Bug: #1400531

commit_message:
Replace the 'release_notes' shell script with a python variant

Instead of using shell script (and the errors prone to its usage)
just use a nice little python script that can provide the same
template and output using jinja2, parawrap (for nicely formatted
paragraphs) and using subprocess so that all return codes are
checked.

This also uses argparse so that a nice help string is generated
and handles the README.rst file not existing or the setup.py file
called upon not existing and so-on.

Change-Id: I2e2969d2188da3c3c33ddb5adc21bdeaff3423f5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator refs/changes/39/141939/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/usr/bin/env python # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. """Generates a standard set of release notes for a repository.""" import argparse import glob import os import subprocess import sys import jinja2 from oslo_concurrency import processutils import parawrap # This will be replaced with template values and then wrapped using parawrap # to correctly wrap at paragraph boundaries... HEADER_RELEASE_TPL = """ The Oslo team is pleased to announce the release of: {{ project }} {{ end_rev }}: {{ description }} For more details, please see the git log history below and: {{ milestone_url }} Please report issues through launchpad: {{ bug_url }} """ # This will just be replaced with template values (no wrapping applied). CHANGE_RELEASE_TPL = """ ---------------------------------------- Changes in {{ lib }} {{ range }}: {% for change in changes -%} {{ change }} {% endfor %} Diffstat (except docs and test files) ------------------------------------- {% for change in diff_stats -%} {{ change }} {% endfor %} Requirements updates -------------------- {% for change in requirement_changes -%} {{ change }} {% endfor %} """ def expand_template(contents, params): if not params: params = {} tpl = jinja2.Template(source=contents, undefined=jinja2.StrictUndefined) return tpl.render(**params) def run_cmd(cmd, cwd=None): # Created since currently the 'processutils' function doesn't take a # working directory, which we need in this example due to the different # working directories we run programs in... p = subprocess.Popen(cmd, stdout=subprocess.PIPE, stderr=subprocess.PIPE, cwd=cwd) stdout, stderr = p.communicate() if p.returncode != 0: raise processutils.ProcessExecutionError(stdout=stdout, stderr=stderr, exit_code=p.returncode, cmd=cmd) return stdout, stderr def main(): parser = argparse.ArgumentParser( prog='release_notes', description=__doc__, formatter_class=argparse.RawDescriptionHelpFormatter) parser.add_argument("--library", metavar='path', action="store", help="library directory, for example" " 'openstack/cliff'", required=True) parser.add_argument("--start-revision", metavar='revision', action="store", help="start revision, for example '1.8.0'", required=True) parser.add_argument("--end-revision", metavar='revision', action="store", help="end revision, for example '1.9.0'" " (default: HEAD)", default="HEAD") args = parser.parse_args() library_path = os.path.abspath(args.library) if not os.path.isfile(os.path.join(library_path, "setup.py")): sys.stderr.write("No 'setup.py' file found in %s\n" % library_path) sys.stderr.write("This will not end well...\n") return 1 # Get the python library/program description... cmd = [sys.executable, 'setup.py', '--description'] stdout, stderr = run_cmd(cmd, cwd=library_path) description = stdout.strip() # Get the commits that are in the desired range... git_range = "%s..%s" % (args.start_revision, args.end_revision) cmd = ["git", "log", "--no-color", "--oneline", "--no-merges", git_range] stdout, stderr = run_cmd(cmd, cwd=library_path) changes = [line.strip() for line in stdout.splitlines() if line.strip()] # Filter out any requirement file changes... requirement_changes = [] requirement_files = list(glob.glob(os.path.join(library_path, '*requirements*.txt'))) if requirement_files: cmd = ['git', 'diff', '-U0', '--no-color', git_range] cmd.extend(requirement_files) stdout, stderr = run_cmd(cmd, cwd=library_path) requirement_changes = [line.strip() for line in stdout.splitlines() if line.strip()] # Get statistics about the range given... cmd = ['git', 'diff', '--stat', '--no-color', git_range] stdout, stderr = run_cmd(cmd, cwd=library_path) diff_stats = [] for line in stdout.splitlines(): line = line.strip() if not line or line.find("tests") != -1 or line.startswith("doc"): continue diff_stats.append(line) # Find what the bug url is... bug_url = '' with open(os.path.join(library_path, 'README.rst'), 'r') as fh: for line in fh: pieces = line.split("Bugs:", 1) if len(pieces) == 2: bug_url = pieces[1].strip() break if not bug_url: raise IOError("No bug url found in '%s'" % os.path.join(library_path, 'README.rst')) lp_url = bug_url.replace("bugs.", "").rstrip("/") milestone_url = lp_url + "/+milestone/%s" % args.end_revision params = { 'project': os.path.basename(library_path), 'description': description, 'end_rev': args.end_revision, 'range': git_range, 'lib': library_path, 'milestone_url': milestone_url, 'bug_url': bug_url, 'changes': changes, 'requirement_changes': requirement_changes, 'diff_stats': diff_stats, } header = expand_template(HEADER_RELEASE_TPL.strip(), params) for line in parawrap.wrap(header): print(line) print(expand_template(CHANGE_RELEASE_TPL.strip(), params)) return 0 if __name__ == '__main__': sys.exit(main())

commit_message:
Made run_tests.sh use tox to run checks

Now run_tests.sh script will use tox to run PEP8 checks.
This will allow to use run_tests.sh in Jenkins build scripts and
that step is required to further improvements of OSTF tests.

This is a step required to unify our CI jobs configuration

Change-Id: I51012b2d633557141baebd5669db256dd5e99efd
Partial-Bug: #1404892
(cherry picked from commit c0e9862e6ab8d846b0db4d3e3ded6142ee3a5f3e)

See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. echo " -p, --pep8 Just run pep8" echo " -P, --no-pep8 Do not run pep8" echo " -h, --help Print this usage message" -P|--no-pep8) no_just_pep8=1;;no_just_pep8=0 function run_tests { # This variable collects all failed tests. It'll be printed in # the end of this function as a small statistic for user. local errors="" # Enable all tests if none was specified skipping all explicitly disabled tests. if [[ $just_pep8 -eq 0 ]]; then if [ $no_just_pep8 -ne 1 ]; then just_pep8=1; fi fi # Run all enabled tests if [ $just_pep8 -eq 1 ]; then run_pep8 || errors+=" pep8_checks" fi # print failed tests if [ -n "$errors" ]; then echo Failed tests: $errors exit 1 fi exit } function run_pep8 { echo "Running pep8 ..." tox -eflake8 -v } run_tests

commit_message:
Create os-cloud-config element

Create an element for installing os-cloud-config, in case there is
ever a time when it is intended to be run from a deployed image,
rather than on the host that is running devtest.

Change-Id: Id126495a4ead2aba00fb33619352dc2daae4acc5
Co-Authored-By: Jon-Paul Sullivan <jonpaul.sullivan@hp.com>

commit_message:
Update service clist commands for v2 and v3

Changes to the 'service list' commands for Identity v2 and v3:
* Document support for --long
* Add Description to v3 output with --long
* v3 output is now (ID, Name, Type), with (Description, Enabled) added with --long
* Change v2 output to match v3 output, with the absense of Enabled.
* Update doc to match

Closes-Bug: #1411337
Change-Id: I999e3df22f61350cdeba63bbb7d01145c2ffeeaf

commit_message:
Use wrapt to provide the deprecated class proxy

Instead of having our own mini-proxy class use the
robustness (and correctness) that the wrapt library
provides to implement a more compliant object proxy
that handles edge-cases better than our own.

Change-Id: Ibc6376d9e9df5df15155db274cf93420ca943927

commit_message:
Open firewall for VNC to Nova compute instances

Existing firewall rules block nova-novncproxy traffic
with the effect that compute instance VNC connections
are not reachable. This change opens up 100 ports
for VNC displays following the scheme suggested by:
http://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Getting_started_with_OpenStack_on_Fedora_17

Change-Id: Ie0e217f465f504c6d87037d7db18ac65bd821d83
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-image-elements refs/changes/21/141521/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: add-rule INPUT -p tcp -m multiport --dports 5900:5999 -j ACCEPT

commit_message:
Add yaml.load to blacklist with yaml example file

yaml.load() allows creation of arbitrary Python objects and is unsafe
with untrusted input. Alert and suggest yaml.safe_load() instead.
Added example file for yaml.load and unit test.

Change-Id: Ie4b109462b4af6bb2c990e4d33d6fabf995134ca
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/bandit refs/changes/24/147924/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - yaml_load: qualname: yaml.load message: "Use of unsafe yaml load. Allows instantiation of arbitrary objects. Consider yaml.safe_load()."

commit_message:
Default user domain id and project domain id

If either of OS_USER_DOMAIN_ID or OS_USER_DOMAIN_NAME are present
then we don't tinker with anything. Otherwise, we should set
the USER_DOMAIN_ID to 'OS_DEFAULT_DOMAIN', as this provides a better UX,
since the end user doesn't have to specify these arguments.

Same logic applies for OS_PROJECT_DOMAIN_ID.

Closes-Bug: #1385338

Change-Id: I8a4034c16a1dd50d269f809abab8e960d5de20f7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-openstackclient refs/changes/52/135152/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # NOTE(stevemar): If USER_DOMAIN_ID or USER_DOMAIN_NAME is present, # then do not change the behaviour. Otherwise, set the USER_DOMAIN_ID # to 'Default' for better usability. if (not self._auth_params.get('project_domain_id') and not self._auth_params.get('project_domain_name')): self._auth_params['project_domain_id'] = 'Default' # NOTE(stevemar): If PROJECT_DOMAIN_ID or PROJECT_DOMAIN_NAME is present, # then do not change the behaviour. Otherwise, set the PROJECT_DOMAIN_ID # to 'Default' for better usability. if (not self._auth_params.get('user_domain_id') and not self._auth_params.get('user_domain_id')): self._auth_params['user_domain_id'] = 'Default'

commit_message:
Add content-type json/yaml for PUT /plan/:id

Partially Implements: blueprint spec/plan-improvements-versionning-and-yaml-support
Related-Bug: #1331093

Change-Id: I1f872c11386a0347a77342ddb34f8db23a4da304
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/solum refs/changes/87/115687/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def content_type_yaml(): try: yml_input_plan = yamlutils.load(pecan.request.body) except ValueError as excp: raise exception.BadRequest(reason='Plan is invalid. ' + excp.message) handler, data = init_plan_by_version(yml_input_plan) return yamlutils.dump(yaml_content(handler.update( self._id, data.as_dict(objects.registry.Plan)))) def content_type_json(): try: json_input_plan = json.loads(pecan.request.body) except ValueError as excp: raise exception.BadRequest(reason='Plan is invalid. ' + excp.message) handler, data = init_plan_by_version(json_input_plan) plan_obj = handler.update(self._id, data.as_dict(objects.registry.Plan)) return wsme_json.encode_result(plan.Plan.from_db_model( plan_obj, pecan.request.host_url), plan.Plan) if (pecan.request.content_type is not None and 'yaml' in pecan.request.content_type): updated_plan_yml = content_type_yaml() else: updated_plan_yml = content_type_json()
deleted_lines: try: yml_input_plan = yamlutils.load(pecan.request.body) except ValueError as excp: raise exception.BadRequest(reason='Plan is invalid. ' + excp.message) handler, data = init_plan_by_version(yml_input_plan) updated_plan_yml = yamlutils.dump(yaml_content(handler.update( self._id, data.as_dict(objects.registry.Plan))))

added_lines: import jsondef init_plan_v1(input_plan): plan_v1 = plan.Plan(**input_plan)def init_plan_by_version(input_plan): version = input_plan.get('version') return getattr(mod, 'init_plan_v%s' % version)(input_plan) @pecan.expose() def content_type_yaml(): try: yml_input_plan = yamlutils.load(pecan.request.body) except ValueError as excp: raise exception.BadRequest(reason='Plan is invalid. ' + excp.message) handler, data = init_plan_by_version(yml_input_plan) return yamlutils.dump(yaml_content(handler.create( data.as_dict(objects.registry.Plan)))) def content_type_json(): try: json_input_plan = json.loads(pecan.request.body) except ValueError as excp: raise exception.BadRequest(reason='Plan is invalid. ' + excp.message) handler, data = init_plan_by_version(json_input_plan) plan_wsme = plan.Plan.from_db_model(handler.create( data.as_dict(objects.registry.Plan)), pecan.request.host_url) return wsme_json.encode_result(plan_wsme, plan.Plan) if not pecan.request.body or len(pecan.request.body) < 1: raise exception.BadRequest if (pecan.request.content_type is not None and 'yaml' in pecan.request.content_type): created_plan = content_type_yaml() else: created_plan = content_type_json() return created_plan
deleted_lines: def init_plan_v1(yml_input_plan): plan_v1 = plan.Plan(**yml_input_plan)def init_plan_by_version(yml_input_plan): version = yml_input_plan.get('version') return getattr(mod, 'init_plan_v%s' % version)(yml_input_plan) @pecan.expose(content_type='application/x-yaml') if not pecan.request.body or len(pecan.request.body) < 1: raise exception.BadRequest try: yml_input_plan = yamlutils.load(pecan.request.body) except ValueError as excp: raise exception.BadRequest(reason='Plan is invalid. ' + excp.message) handler, data = init_plan_by_version(yml_input_plan) create_plan_yml = yamlutils.dump(yaml_content(handler.create( data.as_dict(objects.registry.Plan)))) return create_plan_yml

commit_message:
Create proxy volume driver

Drivers that need a special proxy logic can't inherit from BaseVD
directly. This is problematic for the ABCmeta feature since the class
model can't be accessed easily with isinstance().

Change-Id: I553a72991bb450e8581a757fb98a264ed1ba8fb2
Partly-Implements: blueprint abc-volume-drivers

commit_message:
Capitalize the first letter in log messages.

Capitalize the first letter in the log messages of
cinder/tests/test_emc_xtremio.py to make them look more consistent
with logging in other places.

Change-Id: Ib23248f8d983f5bee31f405c2088b99772a083bd

commit_message:
Specify static defaults rather than variable

* Specify static file name for ulimits rather than using OCF_OCF_RESKEY_binary
  as it may be specified with full path

Change-Id: Ibe740d8aa1d0613997868194fe7154bda145f55b
Closes-Bug: 1405657
Signed-off-by: Sergii Golovatiuk <sgolovatiuk@mirantis.com>

This change will improve the concept of Multitenancy in Keystone.

* Change the format of a returned project hierarchy to better reflect the
  hierarchy;

* Enable recursive deletion of a sub-hierarchy;

* Change the default policy to enable granular control of the hierarchy.

commit_message:
New query params to retrieve the project hierarchy

This change proposes two new query params to retrieve the project
hierarchy: subtree_ids and parents_ids. Both will return just the
project ids in a structured way, reprensenting the hierarchy as it
is.

Co-Authored-By: Henrique Truta <henrique@lsd.ufcg.edu.br>
Co-Authored-By: Rodrigo Duarte <rodrigods@lsd.ufcg.edu.br>
Co-Authored-By: Andrey Brito <andrey@dsc.ufcg.edu.br>

bp hierarchical-multitenancy-improvements

Change-Id: I6663b9a0aa3487f3285572a8fe48e894271b1268
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone-specs refs/changes/09/135309/16 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Hierarchical Multitenancy ========================================== `bp hierarchical-multitenancy <https://blueprints.launchpad.net/keystone/+spec/hierarchical-multitenancy-improvements>`_ Now that we have the base implementation of hierarchical multitenancy in place, we need to improve some functionalities to make it more robust and to improve its usability. Problem Description =================== In the first version, we implemented the basic features for Hierarchical Multitenancy, which included baisc functionalities, such as the following: * Create a project hierarchy, through the addition of the parent_id field; * Get the project parents, subtree and full hierarchy; * Delete projects without children (leaf projects); * Grant/check/revoke role assignments that are inherited down the project hierarchy. Adequate support to hierarchical multitenancy requires improvements such as the following: * Change the format of a returned project hierarchy to better reflect the hierarchy (e.g., a hierarchy of dictionaries); * Enable recursive deletion of a sub-hierarchy; * Change the default policy to enable granular control of the hierarchy (i.e., more granular than the default admin and member roles) Proposed Change =============== 1. Better reflect the project hierarchy in the call the retrieve the API: * The currently implemented GET /projects/{project_id}?subtree_as_list and GET /projects/{project_id}?parents_as_list calls returns a nonstructured list containing the projects in the hierarchy for which the caller has access to. There are some use cases, for example, hierarchical quotas checking (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/129420/), where the full hierarchy is needed, but only the projects IDs are needed and not the complete project information. As the ID does not contain any sensitive information about the project, it could be returned without any constraints (once the caller has access to the get_project operation). * There are two major steps we need to do in order to improve the current implementation: * Implement the new GET /projects/{project_id}?subtree_ids call, which will return the subtree in the form of dictionaries, where every node will have the list of its immediate children. Consider the following hierarchy: +-------------------------------------+ | | | A | | | | / \ | | | | / \ | | | | B C | | | | / \ / \ | | | | / \ / \ | | | | D E F G | | | +-------------------------------------+ * For this hierarchy, when a user requests the subtree_ids from the project A, the following information will be returned: +-------------------------------------+ | | | { | | | | subtree: { | | | | B: { | | | | D: {}, | | | | E: {} | | | | }, | | | | C: { | | | | F: {}, | | | | G: {} | | | | } | | | | } | | | | } | | | +-------------------------------------+ * The same will be done for the GET /projects/{project_id}?parents_ids call. * There will be a constraint that prevents the user from passing "subtree_as_list" and "subtree_ids" filters simultaneously, as well as the "parents_as_list" and "parents_ids". 2. Enable recursive deletion: * The proposal creates recursive deletion, where the children of the requested node will be recursively deleted, after manually disabled. We will follow the current implementation of domains deletion. Disabling projects recursively will be also implemented within this functionality. 3. The policy.v3cloudsample.json should become the default policy.json for Keystone: * To improve the control of the hierarchy, we need to make the policy.v3cloudsample.json the default policy.json for Keystone. * We also need a better definition of what the new roles (cloud_admin, domain_admin, project_admin, project_member) are able to do in Keystone by default. (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/123509/) Alternatives ------------ None Security Impact --------------- None Notifications Impact -------------------- None Other End User Impact --------------------- New API calls must be reflected on python-keystoneclient: * GET the hierarchy; * Option in the API for recursive deletion. Performance Impact ------------------ None Other Deployer Impact --------------------- By changing the default policy file, the name of the roles will change. Developer Impact ---------------- New API calls will be available: * GET the hierarchy; * Create a new option in the API for recursive deletion. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Raildo Mascena (raildo) Other contributors: Rodrigo Duarte (rodrigods) Samuel Medeiros (samuelms) Victor Silva (vsilva) Henrique Truta (henrique-4) Work Items ---------- 1. Implement the new options to get the hierarchy: * Return the hierarchy using a hierarchy of dictionaries instead of a list. 2. Recursive deletion of the hierarchy will be allowed as a two-step process: * The user disables the project or domain which will in turn disable all of the children down the hierarchy; * The user performs a DELETE, which will delete everything under the target domain or project: this will fail if any element of the hierarchy was not disabled. 3. Change the current policy.json for the policy.v3cloudsample.json in Keystone: * Review this patch: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/123509/ * Start to use the policy.v3cloudsample.json as the default policy. Dependencies ============ None Documentation Impact ==================== We must update the API Documentation (Identity API v3) according to these changes. References ========== * `HM Kilo Summit <https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/hierarchical-multitenancy-kilo-summit>`_ * `Keystone Meetup Summit <https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/kilo-keystone-meetup>`_

commit_message:
Revising cleaning spec

This is a follow up patch to the cleaning spec addressing some
questions and concerns on the spec.

Change-Id: I4c3bf9f29e704eb3d704ca35865a37033524104c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs refs/changes/25/147925/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: * Nodes may be put into CLEANING via an API call (described below) only* node.clean_step will be added as a string or None field to track which (/nodes/<uuid>) and node detail API (/nodes/details) should return the current node.clean_step as well.* Security will be improved by adding erasing of disks [3].* If Ironic is updated first, nodes that are torn down may take additional time and will likely time out in unprovision. This would only happen if Ironic was updated before Nova, and a driver that implements clean which takes a large amount of time was enabled and used. This will need to be documented. * Add support for erase_disks in PXE driver * Add cleaning support to IPA * There should be very clear documentation about how cleaning works, how the steps are ordered, what they do, and how operators can enable, disable, and reprioritize them. This is essential for operators to understand if they are going to use cleaning. The differences in between drivers for cleaning will also need to be spelled out. 2: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/102405/ 3: https://bugs.launchpad.net/ironic/+bug/1174153
deleted_lines: * Nodes may be be put into CLEANING via an API call (described below) only* node.cleaning_step will be added as a string or None field to track which (/nodes/<uuid>) and node list API (/nodes) should return the current node.clean_step as well.* If Ironic is updated first, nodes that are torn down may take additional time and will likely time out in unprovision. This would only happen if Ironic was updated before Nova, and a driver that implements clean which takes a large amount of time was enabled and used. This will need to be documented. * Security will be improved by adding erasing of disks.2: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/102405/

commit_message:
Fix default Apache config cleanup on Debian

The configuration file /etc/apache2/conf-available/openstack-dashboard.conf
is not properly cleaned on Debian Operating System.
Source: https://packages.debian.org/wheezy/all/openstack-dashboard-apache/filelist

Change-Id: Idd495fe9ca0adc70eaad2f59a8b3aee212b2e8e5
(cherry picked from commit 3a29f1d51f8fa83dc923bb764069c75b4e5204f3)

commit_message:
subunit_trace.py: take workers into account when reporting total time

Rather than simply summing up the execution time of all tests to
calculate the total run-time, group them all by worker thread, and
use the longest-running worker thread as the definition of Total
Time.

Change-Id: I961bcf628a215092e7c5f064e3c32f21c78e784b
Closes-Bug: 1411395

commit_message:
service_identity: add user/role ordering

If configure_user_role and configure_user are True, we may want to
ensure the user is created before role assignment.

Change-Id: Id21623619c65c5ff1970b43b2d6a3857410a1fd7
(cherry picked from commit 46673d3c793d84e03a766fc1e51f53a52ae8bd8e)

commit_message:
Split share-server deletion test to separate class

tempest/api/share/admin/test_share_servers.py has set of tests and one of them
does not use resources created in setUpClass method at all and waits for it
without reason. Split it to separate class to make it to run in parallel with
other tests.

Change-Id: I580d2caca3b4f1f72adeeb7eb7fc18f92e370635
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/manila refs/changes/51/146051/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

" Skipping.") raise cls.skipException(msg)

commit_message:
Allow CG quota to be showed and updated

This patch added the ability for CG quota to be showed and updated.
- Added consistencygroups as a quota resource to be displayed.
- Added an option for consistencygroups quota to be updated.

Change-Id: I7e88eb426eb1733bce955b7a15b8bffdb1e8ee20
Closes-Bug: #1373766

commit_message:
REST API for angular front end.

This is the start of the API to support the angular front end.

It is missing endpoints not immediately used by angular WIPs other
than the identity re-work, but is enough to start with.

Changes:
- handle additional HTTP status code attribute
- move common helpers from test modules to here

Partially Implements: blueprint angularize-identity-tables

Change-Id: I7495f772be80125fdf52b02883a5b9942db34610

commit_message:
Make numa_usage_from_instances consider CPU pinning

If instance exposes any CPU pinning information, it will be taken into
consideration when calculating NUMA cell usage of the host.

We also add some convenience methods to NUMACell object for pinning and
unpinning CPUs, that will raise an error if the data is inconsistent,
and a wrapper for checking weather CPU pinning was actually requested
(to avoid an error prone 'is not None' in places where the check is
needed).

Change-Id: I43543c526d3733572f4185fbc9aa2207e9b2154c
Blueprint: virt-driver-cpu-pinning
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/15/139615/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from nova import exception def test_free_cpus(self): def test_pinning_logic(self): numacell = objects.NUMACell(id=0, cpuset=set([1, 2, 3, 4]), memory=512, cpu_usage=2, memory_usage=256, pinned_cpus=set([1])) numacell.pin_cpus(set([2, 3])) self.assertEqual(set([4]), numacell.free_cpus) self.assertRaises(exception.CPUPinningInvalid, numacell.pin_cpus, set([1, 4])) self.assertRaises(exception.CPUPinningInvalid, numacell.pin_cpus, set([1, 6])) self.assertRaises(exception.CPUPinningInvalid, numacell.unpin_cpus, set([1, 4])) numacell.unpin_cpus(set([1, 2, 3])) self.assertEqual(set([1, 2, 3, 4]), numacell.free_cpus)

commit_message:
Pass configured fuzzy delay to l3 agent service

Pass the configured fuzzy delay to the l3 agent service initialization
so the periodic routers sync task does not run immediately after startup
if it's not configured to do so.

Closes-Bug: #1411467
Change-Id: I83b438eda036b7b684483d38ab824394120e0cec

  in-core list object first, which could be expensive.

  from the proposed syntax though.  First, it isn't as legible as a
  dict comprehension.  Second, it forces the programmer to create an
  in-core list object first, which could be expensive.
Nova dropped python 2.6 support, we can leverage this now.
There is deep dive about PEP-0274[2] and basic tests about
performance[3].
Note: This commit doesn't handle dict constructor with kwagrs.
This commit also adds a hacking rule.

[1]http://legacy.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0274/
[2]http://doughellmann.com/2012/11/12/the-performance-impact-of-using-dict-instead-of-in-cpython-2-7-2.html
[3]http://paste.openstack.org/show/154798/

Change-Id: Ifb5cb05b9cc2b8758d5a8e34f7792470a73d7c40

commit_message:
Performance: leverage  dict comprehension in PEP-0274

PEP-0274 introduced dict comprehensions to replace dict constructor
with a sequence of length-2 sequences, these are benefits copied
from [1]:
  The dictionary constructor approach has two distinct disadvantages
  from the proposed syntax though.  First, it isn't as legible as a
  dict comprehension.  Second, it forces the programmer to create an
  in-core list object first, which could be expensive.
Nova dropped python 2.6 support, we can leverage this now.
There is deep dive about PEP-0274[2] and basic tests about
performance[3].
Note: This commit doesn't handle dict constructor with kwagrs.
This commit also adds a hacking rule.

[1]http://legacy.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0274/
[2]http://doughellmann.com/2012/11/12/the-performance-impact-of-using-dict-instead-of-in-cpython-2-7-2.html
[3]http://paste.openstack.org/show/154798/

Change-Id: Ifb5cb05b9cc2b8758d5a8e34f7792470a73d7c40

added_lines: return {k: v for k, v in obj.iteritems() if k not in ignored_keys} self.console_data = [{'instance_name': 'name' + str(x), 'instance_uuid': instance_uuid, 'password': 'pass' + str(x), 'port': 7878 + x, 'pool_id': self.console_pools[x]['id']} modified_val = {k: self._cell_value_modify(v, x) for k, v in self._get_cell_base_values().iteritems()} cells_byname = {newcell['name']: newcell for newcell in new_cells}
deleted_lines: return dict([(k, v) for k, v in obj.iteritems() if k not in ignored_keys]) self.console_data = [dict([('instance_name', 'name' + str(x)), ('instance_uuid', instance_uuid), ('password', 'pass' + str(x)), ('port', 7878 + x), ('pool_id', self.console_pools[x]['id'])]) modified_val = dict([(k, self._cell_value_modify(v, x)) for k, v in self._get_cell_base_values().iteritems()]) cells_byname = dict([(newcell['name'], newcell) for newcell in new_cells])

subject: Neutron Pluggable IPAM Blueprint
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-06-04 22:48:54.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs/commit/5f49ff3ab7dfe24e0132e976e82c38a567e9d146', 'message': 'Pluggable IPAM Subsystem in Neutron

This blueprint introduces the pluggable IPAM subsystem in Neutron that allows flexible control over the lifecycle of the network resources like the following:

* Fixed IP addresses assigned to Neutron ports
* Floating IP addresses
* Tenant networks
* Network address ranges i.e. sub-networks

Also see blueprint spec https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/neutron-ipam

Change-Id: I2a44f143056837f9fffa1e70dff8610c52481ff8

commit_message:
Neutron Pluggable IPAM Blueprint

This blueprint introduces the pluggable IPAM subsystem in Neutron
that allows the default IPAM supplied with Neutron to be replaced
by another IPAM. The main use case for this effort is to support
an external IPAM.

https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/neutron-ipam

Blueprint: bp/neutron-ipam

Change-Id: I2a44f143056837f9fffa1e70dff8610c52481ff8

commit_message:
Limit Volume Copy Bandwidth Per Backend

Currently, cinder has a global configuration to limit a volume copy
bandwidth to mitigate slow down of instances volume access during large
image copies. This spec proposes to make this config variable per backend.

blueprint limit-volume-copy-bps-per-backend
Change-Id: Ib854bb9f98c18e5eb5b0d7bfeec84da8003cd520
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder-specs refs/changes/87/106187/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Limit Volume Copy Bandwidth Per Backend ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/limit-volume-copy-bps-per-backend Currently, cinder has a global configuration to limit a volume copy bandwidth to mitigate slow down of instances volume access during large image copies. ( https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/limit-volume-copy-bandwidth ) This spec proposes to make this config variable per backend. Problem description =================== The current global config has some issues. * When multiple backends exist, we cannot assign different bandwidth limit. For instance, it is desirable to allow large bps for SSD than for HDD. * If volume copy runs concurrently, bandwidth larger than the bps limit is consumed. From the viewpoint of QoS (to keep bandwidth for access from instances), we should limit total volume copy bandwidth per backend. Proposed change =============== Move the parameter 'volume_copy_bps_limit' in cinder.conf from DEFAULT section to backend sections. The bps limit is divided if multiple copies runs concurrently. For example, if volume_copy_bps_limit is set to 100MB/s, and 2 copies are running at the same time in a backend, each copy can use up to 50MB/s. If one of the copies finished, the other copy's limit can be updated to 100MB/s. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- On backend driver initialization, create a 'Throttle' class object and put it into '_throttle' member for each backend driver object, that manages the total bandwidth allowed and volume copy operations in flight. It should be passed to copy_volume() as following, so that it can set/update the bandwidth limit. volume_utils.copy_volume(..., throttle=self._throttle) REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ When volume copy I/O bandwidth is limited, it takes more time to complete volume copy. Users are required to balance between volume copy performance and interference to instances performance. Other deployer impact --------------------- * This feature is disabled by default. Users who want to use this feature need to set 'volume_copy_bps_limit' in cinder.conf. Developer impact ---------------- * A '_throttle' member is added to VolumeDriver class, which should be passed to volume_utils.copy_volume() and related function. Otherwise, bandwidth limit will be ignored. * In Linux environments, '_throttle' object will be implemented using cgroups. Drivers for non-Linux environments (e.g. Windows) can override the initialization of '_throttle' to use another method for throttling. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: tsekiyama (tomoki.sekiyama@hds.com) Work Items ---------- 1. Rewrite 'CONF.volume_copy_bps_limit' with 'backend_driver.configuration.volume_copy_bps_limit' etc. 2. Replace current setup_blkio_cgroup() with new 'Throttle' class 3. Pass the Throttle object from the backend drivers to copy_volume() Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= * With volume_copy_bps_limit = 100MB/s for a fake backend driver, * start a volume copy, then the bps limit is set to 100MB/s * start a second volume copy, then the limit is updated to 50MB/s for both * finish one of the copies, then the limit is resumed to 100MB/s Documentation Impact ==================== The cinder client documentation about volume_copy_bps_limit in cinder.conf should address this can be moved to backend driver sections. References ==========

subject: Remove 'SaveOrderTask' and test state in class variables
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-01-14 00:44:32.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/taskflow/commit/82fec6d34b8864ba68aa78911e76577dff5bbc0d', 'message': "Remove 'SaveOrderTask' and test state in class variables (WIP)

Instead of saving task state in a class variable that is later
introspected by further test code just remove that concept (which
doesn't work in multiprocessing or worker engines) and use a
specialized listener that can gather the same information in a more
decoupled manner (and it will work in multiprocessing and worker
engines correctly).

Fixes parts of bug 1357117

commit_message:
Remove 'SaveOrderTask' and test state in class variables

Instead of saving task state in a class variable that is later
introspected by further test code just remove that concept (which
doesn't work in multiprocessing or worker engines which can not
have access those types of shared/globally available concepts due
to how they run) and use a specialized listener that can gather the same
information in a more decoupled manner (and it will work in multiprocessing
and worker engines correctly).

This allows our engine test cases to work in those engine types which
increases those engines test coverage (and future coverage and engine tests
that are added).

Fixes a bunch of occurrences of bug 1357117 as well that were removed
during this cleanup and adjustment process...

Change-Id: Ic9901de2902ac28ec255bef146be5846d18f9bfb

commit_message:
Rename MANAGED to MANAGEABLE

The spec says that states ending with -ING and -ED are active states
(momentary, states that don't need a API call to transition from). The
only exception is the MANAGED state which is a passive state (a state that
needs an API call to transition from). This patch is renaming MANAGED
to MANAGEABLE to get rid of that exception and make naming more consistent
in the new state machine.

Change-Id: I7224c18d6a1afa063249232496f6e34729d7b794

subject: Ensure Pool Manager Works for Multiple Backend Servers
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-01-10 01:27:35.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/designate/commit/758fe8c3775c87ddb03b184e75f82bd91f3c83f9', 'message': 'Ensure Pool Manager Works for Multiple Backend Servers

A few bugs were discovered when working with multiple backend servers.

- Update status for a domain/server is only created after the domain has
  been successfully added to the server.  This ensure MDNS is only called
  for servers with created domains.
- When calculating consensus, the calculation is based on the number of
  servers, not the number of Pool Manager status objects.
- Consensus calculations are done in Decimals, not floats.
- The same code is reused to create domains on failure as is used to create
  domains the first time.
- The same code is reused to delete domains on failure as is used to delete
  domains the first time.
- Unhandled exceptions are trapped if periodic recovery or periodic sync
  encounter them to prevent the threads from dying.  This is logged.

commit_message:
Ensure Pool Manager Works for Multiple Backend Servers

A few bugs were discovered when working with multiple backend servers.

- Update status for a domain/server is only created after the domain has
  been successfully added to the server.  This ensure MDNS is only called
  for servers with created domains.
- When calculating consensus, the calculation is based on the number of
  servers, not the number of Pool Manager status objects.
- Consensus calculations are done in Decimals, not floats.
- The same code is reused to create domains on failure as is used to create
  domains the first time.
- The same code is reused to delete domains on failure as is used to delete
  domains the first time.
- Unhandled exceptions are trapped if periodic recovery or periodic sync
  encounter them to prevent the threads from dying.  This is logged.

Change-Id: I2ae4a7fdc556ce2d9efd5fd91f73dc005c5a8d00
Closes-Bug: 1406414

added_lines: from decimal import Decimalfrom designate.i18n import _LE self.threshold = cfg.CONF['service:pool_manager'].threshold_percentage self._create_domain_on_server( context, create_status, domain, server_backend) self._delete_domain_on_server( context, delete_status, domain, server_backend) if not self._is_delete_consensus(context, domain): status = ERROR_STATUS LOG.warn(_LW('Consensus not reached ' 'for deleting domain %(domain)s') % self.central_api.update_status( context, domain.id, status, domain.serial) LOG.info(_LI('For domain %(domain)s ' LOG.warn(_LW('For domain %(domain)s ' context = DesignateContext.get_admin_context(all_tenants=True) try: self._periodic_create_domains_that_failed(context) self._periodic_delete_domains_that_failed(context) self._periodic_update_domains_that_failed(context) except Exception: LOG.error(_LE('An unhandled exception in periodic recovery ' 'occurred. This should never happen!')) context = DesignateContext.get_admin_context(all_tenants=True) try: self._periodic_notify_servers_zone_changed(context, domains) self._periodic_poll_servers_for_serial_number(context, domains) except Exception: LOG.error(_LE('An unhandled exception in periodic sync ' 'occurred. This should never happen!')) def _create_domain_on_server(self, context, create_status, domain, server_backend): server = server_backend['server'] backend_instance = server_backend['backend_instance'] try: with wrap_backend_call(): backend_instance.create_domain(context, domain) create_status.status = SUCCESS_STATUS self._store_in_cache(context, create_status) LOG.info(_LI('Created domain %(domain)s ' 'on server %(server)s.') % {'domain': domain.name, 'server': self._get_destination(server)}) update_status = self._create_update_status(server, domain) update_status.serial_number = 0 # Setting the update status to ERROR ensures the periodic # recovery is run if there is a problem. update_status.status = ERROR_STATUS self._store_in_cache(context, update_status) # PowerDNS needs to explicitly send a NOTIFY for the AXFR to # happen whereas BIND9 does an AXFR implicitly after the domain # is created. commit_message:
Add authorization by service token to the rescheduling script

Closes-bug: #1275652
Closes-bug: #1322221

(cherry picked from commit 7dd02c88691dbd9074b93ecdd266ecb379a62672)
Change-Id: I759f1330c670923f5b1bad846eff922a8bb25868
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/19/147019/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: OCF_RESKEY_keystone_config_default="/etc/keystone/keystone.conf": ${OCF_RESKEY_keystone_config=${OCF_RESKEY_keystone_config_default}}<parameter name="keystone_config" unique="0" required="0"> <longdesc lang="en"> Location of the Keystone configuration file </longdesc> <shortdesc lang="en">OpenStack Keystone config file</shortdesc> <content type="string" default="${OCF_RESKEY_keystone_config_default}" /> </parameter> setup_auth() { AUTH_TOKEN="" if [[ -f $OCF_RESKEY_keystone_config ]] ; then AUTH_TOKEN=$(grep -v '#' $OCF_RESKEY_keystone_config | grep -i 'admin_token\s*=\s*' | awk -F'=' '{print $2}') fi true } # setup token-based authentication if it possible AUTH_TAIL="" if [[ -n "$AUTH_TOKEN" ]] ; then AUTH_TAIL="--admin-auth-url=${OCF_RESKEY_os_auth_url} --auth-token=${AUTH_TOKEN}" fi bash -c "sleep 33 ; q-agent-cleanup.py --agent=l3 --reschedule --remove-dead ${AUTH_TAIL} 2>&1 >> /var/log/neutron/rescheduling.log " &setup_auth || exit $?

commit_message:
Fix improper parameter setup for cacert and client certs

The client passes cacert incorrectly, CA cert need to be passed
in verify parameter to requests library. Also at present, key file
is not being used, which if it is supplied need to be passed as a
tuple in cert parameter

Python requests library relevant doc link
http://docs.python-requests.org/en/latest/user/advanced/#ssl-cert-verification

Change-Id: Ie71e760bce6a78ed1444373adfa0a133e82ec434
Closes-Bug: 1408372

added_lines: def test_v2_client_cacert_in_verify(self): env = FAKE_ENV.copy() env['cacert'] = '/path/to/cacert' client = self.create_client(env) self.assertEqual(client.client.verify, '/path/to/cacert') def test_v2_client_certfile_and_keyfile(self): env = FAKE_ENV.copy() env['cert_file'] = '/path/to/cert' env['key_file'] = '/path/to/keycert' client = self.create_client(env) self.assertIsInstance(client.client.cert, tuple)

commit_message:
Add decommission to node provision_state API

Included:
* refactor decommissioning work in conductor.manager to its own
  method.
* add RPC call to trigger a decommissioning
* add states.DECOMMISSIONED as a valid input to the
  /nodes/uuid/provision_state API endpoint

Change-Id: I513d9228dead2bb8801f339737ca428753b6a4cb
Co-Authored-By: Jim Rollenhagen <jim@jimrollenhagen.com>
Partial implements: blueprint decom-nodes
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/86/114086/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: 1.18 - Added do_node_decommission. RPC_API_VERSION = '1.18' def do_node_decommission(self, context, node_id, topic=None): """Signal to conductor service to perform a decommission. :param context: request context. :param node_id: node id or uuid. :param topic: RPC topic. Defaults to self.topic. :raises: InstanceDeployFailure :raises: NoFreeConductorWorker when there is no free worker to start async task. The node must already be configured and in the appropriate state before this method is called. """ cctxt = self.client.prepare(topic=topic or self.topic, version='1.16') return cctxt.call(context, 'do_node_decommission', node_id=node_id)

commit_message:
Nova fast deletes while decommissioning

This allows Nova to return a node as deleted to the user before all of the
decommissioning tasks are completed. Decommissioning could potentially take
days, so we should return the node as finished deleting before that.

Change-Id: Ib82a2052716d9c4d2311a19381a30da8bc9b6858

commit_message:
Add a decommission command for the agent

The agent driver needs a way to decommission a node after a workload
has completed. This will store some state in Ironic between states
and let the agent run decommissioning tasks based on the hardware
managers that are installed. After each task, the agent will check
in and optionally pass an argument with the command status requesting
a hard reboot of the node before starting the next task.

Change-Id: I1f840474cbb5b387feddfc5d78f23545c25510ee
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/94/103694/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if response.code == 501: raise NotImplementedError(response.json) def decommission_is_done(self, node): commands = self.get_commands_status(node) if not commands: return False last_command = commands[-1] if last_command['command_name'] != 'prepare_image': # catches race condition where prepare_image is still processing # so deploy hasn't started yet return False if last_command['command_status'] != 'RUNNING': return True return False def decommission(self, node, command, params): LOG.debug('Sending decommission command %(command)s to %(node)s.', {'command': command, 'node': node.uuid}) return self._command(node=node, method='decommission.%s' % command, params=params, wait=False)

subject: Add Node decommission in conductor
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-06-27 00:43:04.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/3ecfb446f63e0eebd8ca95802aed2131a3744e18', 'message': "Add Node decommission in conductor

Add a call to decommission during the tear down calls in the conductor.
The main effect this will have on deploy drivers is they should move
any previous tear_down calls that require a callback to decommission,
because the way the conductor handles tear_down doesn't allow for
callbacks anymore.

Change-Id: I8ea5659af8652c9357812c4c04938d78f4be3833
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-06-27 00:43:17.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/968fd869a15bf73be8cf13e5ecef7823db027022', 'message': "Add Node decommission in conductor

Add a call to decommission during the tear down calls in the conductor.
The main effect this will have on deploy drivers is they should move
any previous tear_down calls that require a callback to decommission,
because the way the conductor handles tear_down doesn't allow for

commit_message:
Add Node decommission in conductor

Add a call to decommission during the tear down calls in the conductor.
The main effect this will have on deploy drivers is they should move
any previous tear_down calls that require a callback to decommission,
because the way the conductor handles tear_down doesn't allow for
callbacks anymore.

Change-Id: I8ea5659af8652c9357812c4c04938d78f4be3833
Partial implements: blueprint decom-nodes

added_lines: DECOMMISSIONING = 'decommissioning' DECOMMISSIONED = 'decommissioned'

commit_message:
Add Node decommission interfaces

Adds the abstract interfaces for node decommissioning in the deploy
interface, along with necessary
additions to the fake and PXE driver to make tests pass. Addtional
patches will begin actually implementing the change.

Change-Id: I1f45ca63a7a83818d59654fb231f2d08ee44b718
Partial implements: blueprint decom-nodes

added_lines: def decommission(self, task): pass def apply_firmware(self, task, device, **kwargs): if device not in self.get_supported_boot_devices(): raise exception.InvalidParameterValue(_( "Invalid boot device %s specified.") % device) def erase_device(self, task, device, **kwargs): if device not in self.get_supported_boot_devices(): raise exception.InvalidParameterValue(_( "Invalid boot device %s specified.") % device)

subject: Freenode has added a +e channel access flag
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-01-16 17:00:38.000000000', 'files': ['accessbot/channels.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/62b6b92f8e11ebb6b270df327b0ddaa7188f3417', 'message': 'Freenode has added a +e channel access flag

Based on the output of 'chanserv help flags' Freenode has added a
new flag: "+e - Exempts from +b and enables unbanning self." This
has been applied automatically to existing administrative access
levels, therefore add it to the accessbot configuration so that the
check script will be aware of it and not break.

Change-Id: I5e50f9c8715b43745851a624eba13d0d4e5785cb
'}]
commit_message:
Freenode has added a +e channel access flag

Based on the output of 'chanserv help flags' Freenode has added a
new flag: "+e - Exempts from +b and enables unbanning self." This
has been applied automatically to existing administrative access
levels, therefore add it to the accessbot configuration so that the
check script will be aware of it and not break.

Change-Id: I5e50f9c8715b43745851a624eba13d0d4e5785cb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/21/147921/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: masters: +AFRefiorstv operators: +Aeforstv channel_op_mask: +AOVefortv full_mask: +AFORVefiorstv

commit_message:
Implement Cleaning States

Add support for cleaning a node after tear_down. Add support
to the management interface to erase disks and apply firmware to
devices.

Change-Id: Ie2c757698acbf2ef5f987143a2235ab7f91f7359
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs refs/changes/85/102685/18 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Support Decommissioning of Nodes ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ironic/+spec/decom-nodes When a node has finished a workload, drivers should have the opportunity to run a set of decommissioning tools and commands during tear down. In order to avoid nodes being stuck in a user's node list as "DELETING" for potentially hours, new states will be introduced between DELETED and NOSTATE, and Nova will return the node as deleted to the user as soon as the node enters these states. Decom will give the driver control over the order of operations and list of required operations in a new decommission() function called after tear_down. The driver can then make calls to ManagementInterface functions or send commands to the ramdisk agent to perform tasks such as firmware updates, reset BIOS settings, erase disks, and other tasks. Problem description =================== * When hardware is recycled from one workload to another, there should be some work done to it to ensure it is ready for another workload. * At a minimum, hard drives should be erased. * Other potentially useful tasks would be firmware updates, resetting BIOS, ensuring the clock is correct, and others. * Users will expect each baremetal node to be the same. Applying these baseline tasks will ensure a smoother experience for end users. * Some users will require certain security measures be taken before a node can be recycled, such as securely erasing disks, which can be implemented on a driver basis. * There is insufficient support in place in Ironic for some of these tasks, such as applying a firmware update which requires a power cycle. * Deployers could use these functions to prepare newly added nodes and set them at the same baseline configuration as existing nodes after they have been created in Ironic * This will likely require either the Ironic Python Agent or a BMC capable of doing the required actions out of band. The current PXE ramdisk would need to be upgraded to support operations like erase_disk() or apply_firmware() as these can't be done over iSCSI. Proposed change =============== * Create a new function in the deploy interface: decommission(task) which will call to the management interface and/or make calls to the ramdisk agent to decommission a node. It will be called by the conductor after tear_down. * Add DECOMMISSIONING AND DECOMMISSIONED to the list of states. * Make the Nova Virt Driver look for DECOMMISSIONING in _wait_for_provision_state() so the node can be removed from a users list of active nodes more quickly. * Add 'decommission_state' and 'decommission_target_state' as top level keys for the node to coordinate reboots and give insight into decommission tasks so nodes aren't rebooted while applying firmware. * Add apply_firmware(task, device, firmware_url) to Management Interface. This will call to the agent or BMC to apply a device firmware. * Add erase_disk(task, disk) to Management Interface. This will call to the agent or BMC to erase a disk. Alternatives ------------ * The drivers could implement this in tear_down only and only using out of band management. It would be slower from a user perspective and unable to do utilize the agent driver to do anything that requires a reboot. * Most of these actions could be taken during deploy. This would significantly lengthen the amount of time to deploy in some cases (especially with spinning disks) Data model impact ----------------- * Add decommission_state and decommission_target_state to Node as top level keys. * Migrations will need to be made to add the new keys. They will default to None. REST API impact --------------- None Driver API impact ----------------- * decommission(task) will be added to the DeployInterface. This will be call after tear_down by the conductor. * erase_disk(task, device) will be added to the ManagementInterface * apply_firmware(task, device, firmware_url) will be added to the ManagementInterface * I don't believe this can be supported in the current PXE driver, only the agent driver and drivers with hardware BMC support, such as iLO. * Testing will be similar to other driver interfaces and each driver will be expected to test their implementation thoroughly. * Existing drivers can choose to not implement the new API with no effect. Nova driver impact ------------------ * Nova driver will look for a new state when determining if unprovision succeeded or not. * If Nova is upgraded first, nothing will change. The driver will continue to be in the tear_down state until the node goes to NOSTATE. * If Ironic is updated first, nodes that are torn down may take additional time and could possibly time out in unprovision. This would only happen if Ironic was updated before Nova, and a driver that implements decommission which takes a large amount of time was enabled and used. Security impact --------------- * Security will be improved by adding erasing of disks and firmware updates. * It should be noted in documentation that there are still attack vectors if baremetal nodes are given to untrusted users or if a baremetal node is compromised. * If the API is called to set a node into a decommission state, that node could be tied up for potentially hours. If run against enough nodes in a cluster by a bad actor, the cluster could run out of capacity quickly. The APIs still require admin access. Other end user impact --------------------- None Scalability impact ------------------ None Performance Impact ------------------ * There will be additional calls to the hardware to perform the decommissioning steps. The steps could take hours, which will mean the time to recycle could be much higher than before. * The node will be locked for the duration of the decommissioning. * Database calls will increase, because the state is saved after each decommissioning step that requires a reboot or long running process. * Rebalances, in the worst case, will require the node to redo one step based on the decommission_state and decommission_target_state fields. This could happen if a conductor dies while it owns a node that is doing a long running process. Other deployer impact --------------------- * Deployer impact won't happen until drivers implement decommission Developer impact ---------------- * Drivers will need to call any functions they deem necessary to decommission a node, and possibly implement those functions. They may add config options to enable or disable those features. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: JoshNang Other contributors: jroll Work Items ---------- * add decommission to the base class and call from the conductor * Add DECOMMISSIONING AND DECOMMISSIONED to the list of states. * Add Nova driver support * Add 'decommission_state' and 'decommission_target_state' as top level keys for the node and add DB migration * Add apply_firmware(task, device, firmware_url) to Management Interface. * Add erase_disk(task, disk) to Management Interface. Dependencies ============ * Firmware Settings would be helpful for drivers to use in their decommission() implementation: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/101122 * External event callback API would be helpful for the Agent driver (and probably others') implementation of decommission: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/99770/ Testing ======= * Drivers implementing decommissioning will be expected to test their added features. Documentation Impact ==================== The management interface and API will need to be documented. References ========== None

commit_message:
Set gw external net to empty for provider networks

Today the gateway_external_network_id is not set
when provider networks are configured. Both the
external_network_id and the gateway_external_network
should be set to empty strings for the provider network
to work with a single l3 agent for multiple external
networks.

Change-Id: Iebb76806a334b9828d892657e16a2334646a5eb0
Closes-Bug: #1410951

commit_message:
Fix tox and add Neutron as project dependency

Before we can start writing tests successfully, there are minor
tweaks to tox that we need to take care of, like adding Neutron
as dependency. Also drop the environments we do not use at the
moment.

commit_message:
Wait for Sahara Cluster to be deleted

Currently the stack with cluster resource depending on cluster template
can not be deleted as the deletion of the cluster template fails since
actually the dependent cluster is not completely deleted yet.

This patch implements check_delete_complete for OS::Sahara::Cluster resource,
allowing the resource to wait until the actual Sahara cluster is deleted
before proceeding along dependency graph.

Change-Id: I9bf3192b34081f045f8165a3b958a7f9a6418ff7
Closes-Bug: #1400540
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/59/141059/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: CLUSTER_STATUSES = ( CLUSTER_ACTIVE, CLUSTER_ERROR ) = ( 'Active', 'Error' ) if cluster.status == self.CLUSTER_ERROR: if cluster.status != self.CLUSTER_ACTIVE: return self.resource_id def check_delete_complete(self, resource_id): if not resource_id: return True try: cluster = self.client().clusters.get(resource_id) except Exception as ex: self.client_plugin().ignore_not_found(ex) LOG.info(_LI("Cluster '%s' has been deleted"), self._cluster_name()) return True else: if cluster.status == self.CLUSTER_ERROR: raise resource.ResourceInError(resource_status=cluster.status) return False
deleted_lines: if cluster.status == 'Error': if cluster.status != 'Active': LOG.info(_LI("Cluster '%s' has been deleted"), self._cluster_name())

commit_message:
Add oslo.messaging._drivers.common for heat tests

Some of the heat unit tests import code from a private part of
oslo.messaging. With the namespace package change, that private part was
no longer being exposed. This change introduces the needed module so we
can release oslo.messaging with the namespace changes without breaking
heat, to give the heat team time to update their tests.

Partial-Bug: #1410196
Change-Id: Ib3ea106646f75b17665877b08ccbd382c5698714

commit_message:
only emit deprecation warnings once

This is a simplified version of what's in master (where all of test.py
was broken up into fixtures, so backporting directly is way too
complicated).

The python warnings module allows you to dial down warnings by
type. This makes a particular warning only emit once per python run,
not on every function call.

Before sqlalchemy-migration >= 0.9.4, migrate reset the warnings
filters everytime migrations are run, so this has to run after any
database code in the setup (otherwise you could make this the first
like of setUp()).

Change-In-Master: b718b52feba694bfe832021dbfbb2f8de5bffaab

Change-Id: I54cb62b64dfd28c4c0981db6a29619e9f7ced488
Partial-Bug: #1407736
(cherry picked from commit 9ee1a0f5756eec1c4ba42bd823b61b09c58e23fa)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/91/147491/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import warnings # We don't need to kill ourselves in deprecation floods. Give # me a ping, Vasily. One ping only, please. warnings.simplefilter("once", DeprecationWarning)
